node.text:
Lyuba's school was bombed beyond recognition in eastern Ukraine. This is what it looks like now.

Hostilities across the world have devastated young people's access to education, and COVID-19 has made things even worse.

Whether living through peace or conflict, children's right to learn must be protected. 

#NotATarget

node.text:
Lyuba's school was bombed beyond recognition in eastern Ukraine. This is what it looks like now.

Hostilities across the world have devastated young people's access to education, and COVID-19 has made things even worse.

Whether living through peace or conflict, children's right to learn must be protected. 

#NotATarget

The public water system in Lebanon is about to collapse.

#worldwaterweek

node.text:
“We have to act now.”

María in Mexico sees how climate change is transforming the world and endangering the most vulnerable - and she’s taking action. #FridaysforFuture

node.title: Advocating for climate justice in Mexico

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by UNICEF on September 13, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, child and standing.

node.text:
"Before, during normal holidays, I could play with my neighbours and my cousins when I visited them, but when schools closed because of COVID-19, we weren't allowed to go and visit families and friends," says 10-year-old Olivier in Rwanda. "I had no one to play with as all my friends had to stay home too. It was difficult for me."

After staying home for eight months Olivier is finally back in the classroom. To support children's learning and mental health, schools must reopen as soon as possible.

© UNICEF/2021/Rudakubana

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by UNICEF on September 13, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
Back to school for girls in Herat, Afghanistan.

Through conflict and COVID-19, UNICEF continues to support education for boys and girls across the country.

But the needs are vast. Over 4.2 million children remain locked out of learning. And according to our most recent data, nearly 50 per cent of girls in Afghanistan have never even entered primary school. This needs to change.

UNICEF continues to press for and closely monitor girls' safety and access to education, as well as the ability of female teachers to return to work.

© UNICEF/UN0518452/Bidel
© UNICEF/UN0518453/Bidel
© UNICEF/UN0518449/Bidel
© UNICEF/UN0518456/Bidel

Photo by UNICEF on September 13, 2021. May be an image of one or more people.

node.text:
"I wish to go to school, play with my friends and have fun sharing our lunch again," says 7-year-old Tarannum from Bangladesh.
 
Like millions of children around the world who are still affected by COVID-19 school closures, Tarannum is eagerly awaiting to get back in the classroom.
 
#ReopenSchools #ForEveryChild

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by UNICEF on September 12, 2021. May be a black-and-white image of one or more people and indoor.

node.text:
“I realized I had left nothing but pain, loneliness and death behind me. Allow me to introduce myself, my name is COVID-19, and I am a monster.”

  14-year-old Anna entered a literary competition to cope with the emotional trauma of COVID-19’s upheaval in Lombardy, Italy. Explore Anna’s story, part of our new photo series 👉 https://uni.cf/generation-covid-italy

@magnumphotos 

© UNICEF/UN0483569/UN0483574/Majoli/Magnum Photos

Photo by UNICEF on September 12, 2021. May be a black-and-white image of one or more people, guitar and indoor.
Photo by UNICEF on September 11, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, people standing, people sitting and indoor.

node.text:
“I'm so happy to be back at school,” says 13-year-old Hazel from Indonesia after almost a year and a half of remote learning. “Studying at school is much better than at home." 
 
From education to mental and physical health, COVID-19 school closures have affected children on so many levels. The sooner we #ReopenSchools, the better. 
 
© UNICEF/UN0515459/Wilander

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by UNICEF on September 11, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, child, people sitting and text that says '"My house fell on me. I had surgery and have been ying down on this bed since the earthquake." Simone, 12 ©UNICEF/UN0516288/Crid unicef for every child'.

node.text:
Since the earthquake struck Haiti, UNICEF has been supporting injured children like 12-year-old Simone by delivering essential medical supplies to hospitals.

Right now, the humanitarian needs of Haitian children are more acute than ever. To scale up access to healthcare, clean water and education, we need urgent funds.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by UNICEF on September 10, 2021. May be an image of child, standing and road.

node.text:
The right for girls and boys to receive a quality education in Afghanistan must be upheld.

#Regram @unicefafghanistan 

In #Herat and other parts of #Afghanistan, primary schools are open again. Our friend and young photographer Omid Haqjoo shared with us what it looks like in his hometown as boys and girls head to #school.

In recent years, significant strides have been made on increasing girls’ access to #education. School enrolment has increased by tenfold from one million children in 2001 to almost 10 million children, including nearly four million girls.

It is vital that gains in education made for children in #Afghanistan are preserved. Access to quality education is both a right and a crucial opportunity #ForEveryChild.

node.text:
Over 100,000 children won't go to school this September because of the devastation caused by Haiti's recent earthquake.

UNICEF, along with the Ministry of Education, is working against the clock to install temporary learning spaces so children can continue their education and receive psychosocial support.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by UNICEF on September 10, 2021. May be an image of text that says '"To have a better future, we all need to learn to take care of our environment." Simon, 17, Haiti'.
Photo by UNICEF on September 09, 2021. May be an illustration of 1 person and text that says 'COME ME TO NEW NORMAL LIFE School Reran'.

node.text:
“I’m excited to go back to school after the long closure due to COVID-19. Maintaining all safety measures, we will again enjoy playing with and talking to friends.”

After over a year of waiting, 11-year-old Rihan from Bangladesh is happy to hear that schools will finally be reopening. What have you been looking forward to most about being back in the classroom?

#ReopenSchools © UNICEF Bangladesh

node.text:
Lyuba's school was bombed beyond recognition in eastern Ukraine. This is what it looks like now.

Hostilities across the world have devastated young people's access to education, and COVID-19 has made things even worse.

Whether living through peace or conflict, children's right to learn must be protected. 

#NotATarget
